title-group.article-title: Structure and Function of Team Learning Emergence
title-group.subtitle: A Multilevel Empirical Validation

abstract.p: The aim of this study is to examine how learning emerges in terms of structure and function to transform from an individual to a collective (team) phenomenon. Drawing on learning theory and multilevel thinking, the authors developed and validated measures for the basic team learning processes (i.e., intuition, interpretation, integration, and codification) in three independent field studies of innovation project teams and employed multilevel structural equation modeling to test relationships across the individual and team levels of analysis. Their results confirm the hypothesis that team learning originates in individual intuitions, is amplified through interpretation and integration, and manifests itself at the team level via the codification of collective cognition and action. Across the three studies, team learning was found to significantly affect team performance. The authors’ approach contributes to a conceptualization and measurement of team learning as a multilevel phenomenon.

body.p: The ever-increasing use of team-based structures in modern organizations has resulted in substantial scholarly work on processes that are hypothesized to influence team performance (for a recent review, see Mathieu, Maynard, Rapp, & Gilson, 2008). Within this body of research, team learning has been proposed as a critical process and has received a considerable amount of empirical examination in real group settings (e.g., Edmondson, 1999; Wong, 2004). The conceptualization and measurement of team learning, however, presents some unique challenges. Because team members work in an interdependent and interactive environment, it is necessary to consider the dynamic interplay between individual members’ knowledge and skills and the team’s collective learning activities (DeShon, Kozlowski, Schmidt, Milner, & Weichmann, 2004), or what Morgeson and Hofmann (1999) described as the emergence form of a collective construct arising from complex individual interactions. Yet research on team learning lacks multilevel examinations of how learning emerges from the cognitions and interactions of individuals to become a group property (Bell & Kozlowski, 2008; Ellis et al., 2003). As Wilson and her colleagues note, “Treatments of group learning confuse levels of analysis by not distinguishing individual learning in the context of groups from group-level learning” (Wilson, Goodman, & Cronin, 2007: 1042).

To date, research has tended to focus on team learning more like a single-level construct by aggregating individual perceptions to create a group mean score. As a result, it fails to recognize team learning emergence and provide explanations of “how disparate individual learning and action emerge as a collective phenomenon” (Kozlowski & Ilgen, 2006: 87). This serious gap in the extant research brings up questions such as, Is it reasonable to refer to teams as if they have learning properties that are inherently human? Are teams able to learn independently of the learning of individual members? By simply aggregating individual contributions, are we committing fallacies of the wrong level and personification (Rousseau, 1985), and hence, are we developing learning constructs that have doubtful scientific validity? Addressing questions such as these becomes increasingly important because of the current proliferation of studies examining learning in work teams and, more importantly, because understanding how learning occurs within socially complex team settings is a critical condition for predicting not only team but also organizational performance (Edmondson, 2002).

The purpose of the present study is therefore to address the above-mentioned gaps by means of multilevel research in an attempt to clarify the structure (i.e., how collective phenomena take shape) and function (i.e., causal effects) of team learning emergence. Structure and function represent the two fundamental dimensions that should be thoroughly examined before any higher level construct can be considered scientifically valid (Li & Cropanzano, 2009; Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999; Ployhart, Weekley, & Baughman, 2006). In this manner, the work at hand makes a number of contributions to the extant literature.

First, using the work of Crossan, Lane, and White (1999) as our starting point, we propose and validate a model of team learning as an emergent phenomenon, where different sociocognitive processes (i.e., intuition, interpretation, integration, and codification) are modeled at different levels, linking the individual with the team. Essentially, in this study we attempt to show how individuals’ cognitions and interactions take shape and emerge as a collective learning phenomenon. For our purposes, the model of Crossan and her colleagues is particularly appropriate, as it is an inherently multilevel conceptualization of how learning unfolds; it draws attention on the importance of intragroup individual interactions and delineates inter alia the fundamental processes determining the nature of learning emergence. Accordingly, the present study offers an explicitly multilevel definition of team learning and empirically examines important, yet untested, propositions about learning emergence in the context of teams, contrary to existing research that does not directly investigate how individual knowledge and learning develop into the team level (Kozlowski & Ilgen, 2006).

Furthermore, this study incorporates—both conceptually and empirically—the inherent dependence of individual members nested within teams. This constitutes a significant addition to the learning and teamwork literature, which have largely developed “imprecise frameworks” because of a lack of attention to the nonindependent nature of real group settings (Mathieu & Chen, 2011). The explicit recognition of this dependence allows us to align the level of theory with the level of measurement (i.e., the unit from which original data are collected) and the level of statistical analysis of the team learning construct, hence avoiding “fallacies of the wrong level” (Hitt, Beamish, Jackson, & Mathieu, 2007). For this purpose, we employ multilevel structural equation modeling (MSEM) to develop measures of team learning processes that capture their multilevel, emergent nature and to test for a functional relationship between team learning and team performance in three different samples of innovation project teams. In so doing, we further provide evidence of discriminant, criterion-related, and incremental validity by comparing our measures with related—but theoretically distinct—constructs and with existing measures or alternative operationalizations of team learning.

Using MSEM, therefore, the present study addresses recent calls regarding the need for a multilevel approach to understanding learning in teams in a way that directly accounts for their nonindependent nature (Chen, Kirkman, Kanfer, Allen, & Rosen, 2007; Kozlowski, Chao, & Jensen, 2010; Kozlowski & Ilgen, 2006) and provides researchers with a set of valid and reliable measures to better theorize and empirically examine the antecedents and consequences of team learning across levels of analysis.

sec.title: Team Learning Research
sec.p: Since the influential work of Senge (1990), who argued that teams comprise the fundamental learning unit in an organization, an increasing amount of research has been carried out to examine learning in teams (e.g., Argote, Gruenfeld, & Naquin, 2001; Bresman, 2010; Edmondson, 1999; Ellis et al., 2003; Gibson & Vermeulen, 2003; Kostopoulos & Bozionelos, 2011; Van der Vegt & Bunderson, 2005; Wilson et al., 2007; Wong, 2004). A team-level approach represents a middle ground for synthesizing individual- with organizational-level learning (Edmondson, 2002), thus offering the potential for a full account of the social milieu within which individual cognition and action—that is, the basic elements of organizational learning (Fiol & Lyles, 1985)—are shaped and translated into collective (team) properties.

Team learning is commonly conceptualized as an ongoing process of action and reflection (Edmondson, 2002) through which teams acquire, combine, and apply knowledge (Argote et al., 2001). This process is closely related to such activities as asking questions, seeking feedback, improvising, discussing errors, challenging underlying assumptions, and reflecting on specific results or unexpected outcomes (Edmondson, 1999). Wong (2004) distinguished between learning activities that occur from interactions within the team, which she referred to as local learning, and activities directed outside the team (i.e., distal learning) and found them to contribute to efficiency and innovativeness, respectively. Team learning, however, also refers to knowledge being encoded and embedded within the team. Gibson and Vermeulen (2003), for instance, underlined the importance of documenting and reflecting on what has been learned through a process of knowledge codification. Codification entails recording teamwork procedures and, thus, converting tacit knowledge into explicit knowledge so that workable outcomes can be developed. Similarly, Wilson and her colleagues (2007) argued that the processes of storing and retrieving knowledge are central dimensions of team learning. Storage and retrieval enable learning to persist over time by retaining knowledge and learned artifacts in memory repositories and by facilitating team members to find and access them for future use.

Although this research is very important, still it seems to provide a rather incoherent account of what constitutes team learning (Wilson et al., 2007). A perhaps more serious problem is that existing conceptualizations do little to explicate how learning emerges from individual members to become a collective property of the team. This raises critical theoretical and empirical questions about the appropriate level of analysis and the processes utilized in current frameworks to clarify how learning attains meaning and structure at the team level (Kozlowski et al., 2010; Wilson et al., 2007).

As a starting point, it is clear that team learning cannot exist without the cognitions and actions of individual members (Argyris & Schön, 1978). It is also true, however, that a collection of individual learners will neither necessarily nor automatically lead to a team in which learning occurs (Fiol & Lyles, 1985). What we can safely suggest is that those team members’ unique ideas, insights, and behaviors constitute the foundation from which learning emerges as a team-level phenomenon (DeShon et al., 2004; Kozlowski & Ilgen, 2006). Hence, a central theme to address is how team learning emerges out of individual learning. How do individuals interact and influence each other to develop collective learning perceptions? What are the sociocognitive processes that underlie these interactions? How does learning become a team property that transcends individual members? As yet, extant research lacks adequate explanations to these questions; the use of multilevel thinking can be an effective means to move forward.

sec.title: Team Learning as a Multilevel, Emergent Phenomenon
sec.p: Given the aforementioned limitations in the literature, we build on multilevel theory to conceptualize team learning as an emergent phenomenon that traverses individual and group levels to rise as a collective property of the team. A construct is emergent “when it originates in the cognition, affect, behaviors, or other characteristics of individuals, is amplified by their interactions, and manifests as a higher-level, collective phenomenon” (Kozlowski & Klein, 2000: 55). Therefore, to conceptualize team learning as an emergent phenomenon, we need to carefully investigate individual contributions (e.g., cognition, insights, ideas) as well as the system of cross-member interactions (e.g., knowledge sharing, collective sense making, influences on each others’ actions and behaviors) that enable learning to arise as a team property (DeShon et al., 2004; Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999).

Individual cognition and actions have long been recognized as the elemental content of organizational learning (Fiol & Lyles, 1985). Individuals within organizations, however, do not think and act in a (social) vacuum. Their cognition and behaviors are affected and bounded by the surrounding context within which they operate (e.g., project teams, departments, business units), and thus, the acceptable range of their actions is shaped by a variety of situational or contextual factors. Morgeson and Hofmann (1999: 251), following Allport’s (1967) view on collective behavior, describe this intersection of individual action in its context as the “ongoings of the individual system.” Individual ongoings inevitably encounter one another, leading to a system of interpersonal events where individuals stimulate each other’s actions and reactions. Team members, for example, share information and resources, communicate moods and feelings, engage in sense making, and perform activities that exert influences and generate successive responses by others. As this interaction unfolds in a circular and recurrent pattern, a structure of collective action emerges, which transcends individuals and forms the basis for the development of team learning as a higher level construct (Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999). Therefore, team learning emerges from the ground up, with individual members’ interactions being the building blocks of the emerging collective structure.

This ground-up approach to team learning creates the need for an underlying theoretical framework that clarifies the structure of its emergence (Kozlowski & Klein, 2000; Mathieu & Chen, 2011). We adopt as our theoretical starting point the learning model developed by Crossan and her colleagues (1999). Their work offers a compelling conceptual basis that specifies the sociocognitive processes through which learning unfolds. Four characteristics of Crossan et al.’s model are particularly important to conceptualizing learning as a collective phenomenon: (1) It is a multilevel model by its very construction, linking the individual through the team to the organization level of analysis; (2) it identifies the mechanisms and interaction dynamics that bridge the levels through four processes—intuition, interpretation, integration, and institutionalization; (3) it emphasizes the emergent and contingent nature of these processes, with learning being conditional on the individuals involved and the group context within which these processes take place; and (4) it captures the ongoing interplay between cognition and action, which, as previously noted, constitutes a fundamental characteristic of any learning theory (Fiol & Lyles, 1985). For our purposes, we utilize the first three of these processes (i.e., intuition, interpretation, and integration) as originally theorized and reconceptualize the fourth (i.e., institutionalization) as learning being codified and embedded into the team level (Gibson & Vermeulen, 2003), not the organizational level, of analysis.1

Crossan et al. define intuition as “the preconscious recognition of the pattern and/or possibilities inherent in a personal stream of experience” (1999: 525). Intuition is, of course, situated within the individual. Individuals explore, improvise, and develop novel solutions or recognize opportunities based on previous experience and their ability to identify underlying or potential patterns in that experience (Dane & Pratt, 2007). These intuitive insights and ideas may act as “mental moderators” to individuals’ learning tendencies and preferences (Bargh & Chartrand, 1999) and are typically generated in a tacit or preverbal form (Hogarth, 2001). Hence, they have to be converted and articulated in terms of metaphors, which may be the only possible means of communicating individual insights with other team members.

While intuition focuses on the subconscious development of individual insights, interpretation acts as a “feed-forward” mechanism that links the individual and team levels through conversation and dialogue (Crossan et al., 1999). Interpretation is defined as “the explaining, through words and/or actions, of an insight or idea to one’s self and to others” (Crossan et al., 1999: 525). With a predominantly social character, interpretation involves dialectical interactions within a group context, through which individual members share and refine their intuitions, negotiate meaning, and build a common language. In this way, members develop their cognitive maps and begin to name and explicate previously unstructured ideas, half-thoughts, or feelings. The process of interpretation, therefore, facilitates the development of shared understanding among team members, thus enabling members’ cognitive schemas to converge regarding critical domains of their task environment (Weick & Roberts, 1993). For Crossan and her colleagues, interpretation “bridges” the individual with the collective (i.e., the team) in which it (the individual) is embedded.

Integration, in turn, is a process that takes place at the team level (Bontis, Crossan, & Hulland, 2002). Once intuitive insights have been translated into a convergent, shared interpretation, they have the potential to be integrated into the activities of the team. Crossan et al. refer to integration as “the process of developing shared understanding among individuals and of taking coordinated action through mutual adjustment” (1999: 525). The process of integration has an explicit orientation toward the accomplishment of coherent, collective action. Through continuing communication and shared practice, members’ distributed activities tend to converge, generating actions upon which all team members agree and participate.

Finally, the collective action and the ensuing knowledge created in the course of interactions among members need to be codified and embedded into the team (e.g., stored in written documents or in electronic databases and reporting systems) so that learning can persist and produce workable outcomes. As Gibson and Vermeulen note, codification “enables a team to put knowledge and ideas into practice and reflect and build on what has been learned” (2003: 206). In the absence of codification, a team may fail to learn and thus may be unable to contribute new explicit knowledge in memory repositories or produce new ways of working that could help its members and the broader organization to perform effectively in a future situation (Edmondson, 2002).

Taken together, the sociocognitive processes of intuition, interpretation, integration, and codification delineate the emergent character of learning in team settings. Team learning originates in individual intuitions that involve previous experiences and creative insights on a common task. These largely amorphous cognitive elements of individual members are filtered and shaped by the social process of interpretation; personal insights are blended with those of other individuals in the group through a system of dialectical interactions. Team members work together, communicate and share knowledge, transform their intuitive perspectives into explicit concepts, and influence each other toward a uniform interpretation of their team task. Potential variations in individual perceptions tend to dissipate, as only those interpretations that are accepted by all members will converge to a shared team understanding. As this shared understanding is repeatedly enacted, team members choose the type of actions that the team should perform through the process of integration. Through integration, cognitive elements (i.e., common interpretation and shared understanding) are translated into mutual action (i.e., coordinated behaviors and team activities). It is in this sense that cognition–action interrelationships emerge as collective team learning (Crossan et al, 1999; Edmondson, 2002; Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999). Finally, collective cognition and action have to be converted into explicit outcomes through codification. Documenting and codifying what has been learned ensures that learning has actually taken place and will endure as an emergent property of the team, “exerting influence beyond the individual members involved in the original learning process” (Wilson et al., 2007: 1043).

Based on the discussion above, we argue that intuition, interpretation, integration, and codification are different sociocognitive processes that affect and complement each other and, jointly, compose team learning. Hence, team learning is more than the simple sum of these four processes. Rather, it is reflected in the pattern of interrelations (Venkatraman, 1989) among these processes, seen as constitutive dimensions of a higher (second-) order, emergent phenomenon, which originates in individual intuitions, is amplified through interpretation and integration, and materializes at the team level via the codification of collective cognition and action. Properly testing learning emergence in our context requires the specification of a two-level model where the different processes identified above are located at the level prescribed by theory, team learning is represented as a second-order factor, and the model fit the data.

Furthermore, a thorough examination of the discriminant validity of our multilevel, higher order factor structure of team learning necessitates comparisons with related, but theoretically distinct, group constructs, such as coordination and communication. Team coordination, referring to the process of synchronizing team members’ activities with respect to their sequence and timing (Marks, Mathieu, & Zaccaro, 2001), and team communication, referring to the exchange of information among team members (Pinto & Pinto, 1990), are considered as fundamental group processes (Mathieu et al., 2008). We expect these constructs to be related to, but distinct from, team learning (Wong, 2004). Hence, we hypothesize:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1a: Team learning is an emergent phenomenon represented as a second-order factor composed of different processes at different levels of analysis.
Hypothesis 1b: Team learning will be related to, but distinct from, team coordination and communication.

sec.title: Team Learning and Its Functional Relationship to Performance
sec.p: Multilevel theory further asserts that to fully understand a higher level construct, one should also examine its function, that is, the effects or outputs it generates within an organizational system (Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999; Ployhart et al., 2006). In recent years, scholars have begun to study the function of team learning by exploring its effects on team efficiency and effectiveness (Edmondson, 1999; Wong, 2004), on quality of intrateam relations (Zellmer-Bruhn & Gibson, 2006), or on the implementation of new practices (Tucker, Nembhard, & Edmondson, 2007). As noted above, however, we argue that this work still lacks conceptual and measurement rigor, as it fails to examine team learning as a collective, emergent phenomenon.

The most obvious function of team learning is its capacity to affect team performance (Mathieu et al., 2008). Team performance can be generally defined as the extent to which a team is able to meet its output goals (e.g., quality, functionality, and reliability of outputs), the expectations of its members, or its cost and time objectives (Ancona & Caldwell, 1992). Using performance as the dependent variable in a functional analysis illustrates the critical role of learning in a collective team environment and allows us to better evaluate the construct validity of our team learning construct by unraveling the very processes through which learning emerges as a collective phenomenon from its performance outcomes (Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999; Wilson et al., 2007).

In most studies, team learning has been shown to enhance efficiency-based facets of team performance (e.g., adherence to budget and time schedules). The basic line of reasoning for these positive effects is that learning facilitates a team to adapt to changing circumstances, to continually refine procedures and practices, and to implement new and better ways of achieving its objectives (Edmondson, 1999; Edmondson & Membhard, 2009). It has also been suggested, however, that learning may not invariably lead to higher team effectiveness and may even be dysfunctional under certain circumstances. Teams that overemphasize learning could suffer the costs of experimentation without (necessarily) gaining concrete performance benefits (Levinthal & March, 1993), may consume time without assurance of results, or may produce more variation than can be effectively assimilated and integrated into group operations (Bunderson & Sutcliffe, 2003). Nevertheless, for teams working on nonroutine tasks (e.g., innovation development teams), learning may be argued to represent a sine qua non condition for generating novelty and for producing innovation under market and technological uncertainties (Edmondson & Membhard, 2009). Hence, in such challenging and demanding circumstances the benefits of learning are expected to outweigh the potential risks (Choo, Linderman, & Schroeder, 2007; Kostopoulos & Bozionelos, 2011).

By engaging in the sociocognitive learning processes identified above, teams are able to adapt to or even take advantage of shifting task requirements (Bontis et al., 2002; Gibson & Vermeulen, 2003). Hoopes and Postrel’s (1999) study of new product development teams demonstrated that teams with greater common task knowledge were able to perform better, as shared knowledge outweighed possible glitches or coordination errors arising from misunderstandings. In a similar vein, other studies (e.g., Dougherty, 1992; Marks, Sabella, Burke, & Zaccaro, 2002) have shown that learning improves team performance by facilitating information sharing and the harmonization of activities among members carrying out innovative tasks. Effective learning will therefore permit a more accurate understanding of the tasks at hand, as well as of the broader environment within which the team operates; will foster creative actions; and will ultimately enable the team to accomplish its goals successfully (Wong, 2004).

In addition, we expect that our multilevel, higher order factor structure of team learning would better predict performance than existing measures of team learning, such as Edmondson’s (1999) seven-item scale or an alternative operationalization (i.e., average scores) of our team learning items. This is because our proposed factor structure allows for a better alignment between the level of theory with the level of measurement and the level of statistical analysis of the team learning construct (Chan, 1998; Klein, Conn, Smith, & Sorra, 2001), thus offering an unbiased estimation of model parameters and measurement error across levels of analysis. Hence, we hypothesize:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2a: Team learning will be positively related to team performance.
Hypothesis 2b: The multilevel, second-order factor structure of team learning will better predict performance than existing measures and alternative operationalizations of team learning.

sec.title: Samples, Analyses, and Measurement Procedures
sec.p: Data were collected in three different studies, which were designed to (a) develop scales to measure team learning processes (i.e., intuition, interpretation, integration, codification), based on Crossan et al. (1999) and related work (e.g., Edmondson, 1999; Gibson & Vermeulen, 2003), and (b) examine the structure and function of team learning emergence. For these purposes, we followed standard and multilevel scale development procedures and analytic techniques described in the relevant literature (e.g., Ashill & Jobber, 2010; Chen, Mathieu, & Bliese, 2004; Dyer, Hanges, & Hall, 2005; Nunnally & Bernstein, 1994). In particular, Study 1 focused on generating a set of items that fully represented the four sociocognitive processes of team learning and on assessing their content validity, dimensionality, and reliability. Study 2 was an attempt to examine the emergent nature of team learning by confirming the factor structure (i.e., different factors at different levels) and constructs’ dimensionality and to provide evidence of convergent, discriminant, criterion-related, and incremental validity, using MSEM. Finally, Study 3 aimed at replicating the factor structure and demonstrating construct validity for the team learning scale (again employing MSEM) in a different multicountry data set. In all three studies, we surveyed teams that had completed innovative assignments (i.e., development of a new product or service, technology, or introduction and adoption of a new process or management system) up to three months before data collection. These teams were time limited and were composed of managerial staff, engineers, and scientists.

The principal analytic technique employed was MSEM. MSEM is a relatively new field of methodological research (Bauer, 2003; Cheung & Au, 2005; Croon & van Veldhoven, 2007; Liang & Bentler, 2004) that explicitly addresses the nonindependent nature of hierarchically nested data often encountered by management scholars (in our context, multiple respondents rating various features of the same team). In simple terms, MSEM consists of a concurrent analysis of both the within-group (i.e., individual-level) and between-group (i.e., team-level) covariance matrices. Therefore, MSEM, unlike its single-level counterpart or other more traditional approaches (e.g., aggregation), simultaneously considers the effects of intragroup dependency and between-groups differences, thus allowing an unbiased estimation of model parameters and measurement error at both the individual and team levels of analysis (Croon & van Veldhoven, 2007; Dyer et al., 2005). More importantly, by employing MSEM, researchers are able to demonstrate an appropriate (based on their theories) factor structure that may differ across levels, thus testing for emergence (i.e., Hypothesis 1a), and examine functional relationships at the desired level of analysis (in our case, learning effects on team performance—i.e., Hypothesis 2a; Hanges & Dickson, 2006).

Team learning processes and team performance were measured with Likert-type items (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) using direct consensus and referent-shift compositional formats. Consistent with our conceptualization of team learning as a collective property emerging bottom-up, our measures attempted to gauge learning processes as individual perceptions with respect to intuition and as shared perceptions of team members with respect to interpretation, integration, and codification. It needs to be emphasized that whenever lower level (e.g., individual) data are collected to measure and make inferences about higher level (e.g., team) phenomena, researchers usually adopt (implicitly or explicitly) a composition model (Chan, 1998; Klein et al., 2001). Direct consensus and referent-shift measures employed in the context of compositional models, based on assumptions of isomorphism, describe constructs that maintain the same meaning across levels (Chen et al., 2004; Kozlowski & Klein, 2000). Had we theorized team learning as a combination of diverse individual-level contributions, we would have employed a compilation model of measurement (see, e.g., Kozlowski, Gully, Nason, & Smith, 1999).

Specifically, in keeping with our basic premise that team learning is an emergent phenomenon transcending from the individual to the collective, we employed a direct consensus format to measure intuition (i.e., utilizing “I” referenced items; see Chen et al., 2004) and a referent-shift format to measure interpretation, integration, codification, and team performance (i.e., utilizing “we” referenced items). According to Crossan et al. (1999), the learning process of intuition is situated within the individual, not the team; thus individual (“I”) referents should be an appropriate measurement approach. An example item used for rating intuition was (for details, see Table 1): “I could effectively improvise in this team.” Conversely, the processes of interpretation,2 integration, and codification are considered to take full shape at the level of the team (Crossan et al., 1999). Hence, for these learning processes we used items that shifted the referent from the individual member (“I”) to the team as a whole (“we”; Chan, 1998; Chen et al., 2004). An example item used for measuring integration was (see Table 1): “In our team, we managed to agree upon the actions and activities that we should perform.” As Morgeson and Hofmann note, “Inferences at the collective [team] level will be facilitated by focusing on collective phenomena, framing questions in collective terms, treating individuals as informants about collective processes” (1999: 261).

sec.title: Study 1: Scale Development and Initial Validation
Item generation and content validity
sec.p: Based on Crossan et al.’s (1999) conceptual model and on other existing measures of team learning (Edmondson, 1999; Gibson & Vermeulen, 2003; Wong, 2004), we followed established scale development procedures (e.g., Nunnally & Bernstein, 1994) to first generate a pool of 24 items that fully represented the four team learning processes. The work of Bontis et al. (2002) was also reviewed, as it is, to our knowledge, the only study that attempted to operationalize Crossan et al.’s framework. Nevertheless, Bontis et al. focused on measuring stocks and flows of organizational learning rather than specific processes that could explicate the emergence of learning as a team-level phenomenon.

Eight independent reviewers from industry and academia, experienced in team operations and related research, examined the initial pool of 24 items to verify content validity and to identify ambiguous wording and redundant items. Based on their comments, we excluded 2 items from further analysis and rephrased 4, reducing the pool to 22 items (5 for intuition, 7 for interpretation, 6 for integration, and 4 for codification).

sec.title: Dimensionality and reliability
sec.p: To further purify the measures and assess dimensionality, we subsequently tested items in two stages. In the first, 12 in-depth interviews with senior executives were carried out by the first author to examine the clarity and practical relevance of the measures. Each interview lasted approximately one hour and, based on interviewees’ judgments, 15 out of the 22 items were retained (3 for intuition, 5 for interpretation, 4 for integration, and 3 for codification).

In the second stage, we conducted an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) on a sample of 271 executives attending graduate courses at a large European business school who had recently participated in project teams. All participants completed anonymous surveys in English during class time (participants were proficient in the English language). The average age of the participants in this sample was 34.2 years (SD = 4.5), 65% were male, and the average organizational tenure was 4.8 years (SD = 3.8). EFA was performed using principal component analysis with oblique rotation and eigenvalues greater than 1 as the criterion for factor extraction. Oblique rotation was selected because it has been shown to be more effective, compared to orthogonal rotation, at the early stages of scale development due to the fewer constraints it imposes (Hair, Black, Babin, Anderson, & Tatham, 2006). Furthermore, oblique rotation was most appropriate, as team learning processes are expected to correlate with one another.

After removing 3 items that either did not load significantly on any factor or loaded highly (above .40) on more than one factor, a four-factor solution was obtained with 12 items loading as expected and well above the conservative cutoff level of .5 (see Table 1; Hair et al., 2006). The percentage variance explained for each of the four factors was as follows: intuition 14.8% (eigenvalue: 1.8), interpretation 35.3% (eigenvalue: 4.2), integration 12.5% (eigenvalue: 1.5), and codification 20.7% (eigenvalue: 2.5). The cumulative variance explained for all four factors was 83.3%. The reliability of those factors was also quite satisfactory. Cronbach’s alphas for the four learning processes were .81, .94, .91, and .89, respectively. Moreover, the existence of moderate-to-high intercorrelations among the factors (ranging from .12 to .57) confirmed the (implicit) assumption that the four processes represent dimensions of a higher order team learning factor. Overall, these results provide a reasonable degree of confidence on the dimensionality and reliability of the scales.

sec.title: Study 2: Multilevel Construct Validation: Emergence and Functional Effects
Sample and procedures
sec.p: Data from innovation project teams operated within the information and communication technology (ICT) and the pharmaceutical sectors in Greece were used to confirm the construct validity of the scales, as purified in Study 1, and to examine the structure and function of team learning as a second-order, emergent phenomenon. Two separate questionnaires in English were administered to team members and team supervisors, assuring anonymity and confidentiality (all participants were proficient in English). Team supervisors were managers formally assigned to monitor and evaluate team performance. Team members’ questionnaires contained measures of team learning processes, whereas supervisors’ questionnaires measured team performance. This procedure mitigated the possibility of common method bias, as different informants were utilized to assess the intragroup variables (i.e., learning processes) and team performance. Team performance was measured with five Likert-type items adopted from Ancona and Caldwell (1992) and Oh, Chung, and Labianca (2004), which captured both the efficiency and effectiveness facets of performance.

We initially contacted by phone 85 firms in the ICT industry and 58 firms in the pharmaceutical industry. Fifty ICT and 35 pharmaceutical firms agreed to participate, for an overall response rate of 59%. From these firms, we managed to initially recruit 153 project teams (93 and 60 teams from ICT and pharmaceutical companies, respectively). Next, the first author conducted personal interviews with members and supervisors of those teams. To ensure that there were enough respondents to accurately reflect their teams, we followed the widely used response criterion of three or more completed questionnaires from team members and a completed questionnaire from the supervisor (see, e.g., Hinds & Mortensen, 2005; Van der Vegt & Bunderson, 2005; Van der Vegt & Janssen, 2003; Zhang, Hempel, Han, & Tjosvold, 2007). This led us to omit 14 teams from further analyses. Hence, the final sample for Study 2 consisted of 139 project teams from 85 ICT and 54 pharmaceutical companies, corresponding to a 90.8% team-level response rate, with 661 team members (the mean percentage of members surveyed from each team was 64%) and 139 supervisors. These response rates were deemed comparable with those achieved in similar studies on project teams (e.g., Choo et al., 2007; Haas, 2010; Tucker et al., 2007; Zhang et al., 2007). Team size ranged from 4 to 15 members (M = 7.4, SD = 1.9), and mean project duration was 12.2 months (SD = 8.9). The average age of participants in this sample was 33.4 years (SD = 3.7), and 74.5% were male.

sec.title: Multilevel analyses and results
sec.p: As previously mentioned, given the inherently multilevel nature of our conceptual model, we employed MSEM as our primary analytic technique in this and the subsequent study (cf. Bentler & Liang, 2003; Muthén, 1994). In particular, we used Muthén’s (1994) five-step procedure to assess the multilevel structure of data and examine the emergence of learning at the team level (for recent applications of Muthén’s procedure, see Cheung & Au, 2005; Dyer et al., 2005; Hirst, Van Knippenberg, & Zhou, 2009). The first step involves a conventional structural equation modeling (SEM) analysis on the sample total covariance matrix (i.e., ignoring the multilevel nested data structure) that provides a rough (and most likely biased) estimate of fit of the proposed model. The second step pertains to an estimation of between-group variation—through computing the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC), 1 – ICC(1)—that demonstrates whether multilevel analysis is appropriate for the data at hand. The third and fourth steps involve a SEM analysis on the sample pooled within-group (i.e., individual level) and between-group (i.e., team level) covariance matrix, respectively. The pooled within-group covariance matrix is corrected for between-group differences by subtracting relevant group means from individual scores, while the between-group covariance matrix is the covariance matrix of observed group means corrected for the grand mean (Dyer et al., 2005). The fifth and final step entails the actual multilevel analysis that provides an unbiased estimation of both the within- and between-groups factor structure.

Figure 1 presents a graphical representation of our model. Recall that we hypothesize (Hypothesis 1a) team learning to be a second-order, emergent phenomenon in that different processes are modeled at different levels of analysis. Following Crossan et al. (1999), we expect that intuition is an individual-level process; interpretation links the individual with the team level, acting as a bridging mechanism, while integration and codification are realized at the team level of analysis. These four processes define the structure of the sociocognitive processes by which team learning emerges as a collective, second-order phenomenon. Even though rooted in the cognitions and insights of individuals, team learning has a conceptual, as well as a pragmatic, meaning only at the higher (team) level of analysis (Kozlowski & Klein, 2000). Hence, our statistical representation of learning emergence treats team learning as a second-order latent factor at the team level of analysis, composed of the first-order latent factors of interpretation (modeled at both the individual and team levels), integration and codification (both modeled at the team level), and intuition (modeled at the individual level). Finally, as per Hypothesis 2a, team learning (as a second-order factor) is expected to affect team performance positively.

sec.p: All analyses were performed using full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimates in the EQS 6.1 structural equations program (Bentler, 2004) that has features specifically accommodating multilevel analysis. FIML (Bentler & Liang, 2003), unlike Muthén’s (1994) maximum likelihood estimator, offers a more robust estimation of standard errors and is likely more appropriate in situations of unbalanced data (i.e., where group sizes are different), such as those encountered in the current study (Bauer, 2003; Cheung & Au, 2005). Various indices were utilized to determine multilevel model fit. Specifically, model fit was first assessed with the Bentler-Liang likelihood ratio statistic, which is the multilevel equivalent of the chi-square goodness-of-fit statistic (Bentler & Liang, 2003). In addition, we also used comparative fit index (CFI), normed and incremental fit indices (NFI and IFI), and the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA). Due to lack of standard cutoff levels for these fit indices in multilevel analysis, we followed conventional SEM recommendations (e.g., values of CFI above 0.95 and values of RMSEA below 0.08; Hu & Bentler, 1999), recognizing, however, that further research is needed to confirm these benchmarks in the context of MSEM (Mathieu & Chen, 2011). Regarding sample size, multilevel researchers propose that the number of higher level clusters (i.e., number of teams), rather than the total number of participants (i.e., individual team members), should be used as a comparable number to regular SEM (Mehta & Neale, 2005). A team-level sample size should be at least 100 in order to reach reliable conclusions using MSEM (Cheung & Au, 2005). Our sample of 139 project teams clearly exceeded this size benchmark.

Following Muthén’s (1994) five-step procedure, we first performed a confirmatory factor analysis at the individual level (i.e., N = 661) on the four team learning processes and on team performance. The primary purpose of this analysis was to verify the factor structure identified using EFA in Study 1 (see Table 1) and to provide evidence of convergent and discriminant validity. Therefore, we constructed a model with five factors (i.e., intuition, interpretation, integration, codification, and team performance) loading separately; for the five-factor model, Satorra-Bentler scaled χ2(109) = 223, p < .001, CFI = .98, NFI = .97, IFI = .98, RMSEA = .04. All factor loadings were high (ranged from .68 to .96) and significant (p < .001).

We also tested whether more parsimonious four- (combining interpretation and integration), three- (combining interpretation, integration, and codification), and two-factor (all learning indicators loaded on one factor) models provided better fit to the data; for the four-factor model, Satorra-Bentler scaled χ2(113) = 1,032.1, p < .001, CFI = .88, NFI = .87, IFI = .87, RMSEA = .11; for the three-factor model, Satorra-Bentler scaled χ2(116) = 1,976.2, p < .001, CFI = .76, NFI = .75, IFI = .76, RMSEA = .16; for the two-factor model, Satorra-Bentler scaled χ2(118) = 3,377.2, p < .001, CFI = .59, NFI = .58, IFI = .59, RMSEA = .21. The proposed five-factor model at the individual-level data performed better than all alternative models, thus providing evidence of convergent and discriminant validity for the constructs studied (Bagozzi, Yi, & Phillips, 1991). Moreover, the existence of moderate-to-high covariances (ranging from .18 to .50) among the four factors representing team learning processes confirmed the assumption that these are all dimensions of a higher order team learning factor.

Subsequently, we computed in EQS 6.1 the ICC(1) for each factor item in order to determine the level of between-group variance. The ICC(1) values for all items ranged from .29 to .42, demonstrating sufficient between-group variation to statistically warrant the use of multilevel analysis (Dyer et al., 2005; James, 1982). Therefore, we then conducted the final-step MSEM3 on the sample pooled within-group and between-group covariance matrices (Table 2). Specifically, our model tests simultaneously whether (a) team learning is a second-order latent factor at the team level composed of first-order latent factors represented at both levels (Hypothesis 1a) and (b) team learning affects team performance (Hypothesis 2a).

sec.p: Results (FIML estimates; Table 3) indicated that our proposed multilevel model fitted the data very well, Bentler-Liang likelihood ratio statistic (123) = 184.8, p < .001, CFI = .99, NFI = .97, IFI = .99, RMSEA = .02. The first-order factor loadings at both the within (individual) and between (team) levels were high (ranging from .60 to .97) and significant (p < .001). Regarding the higher level latent factor of team learning, the second-order standardized paths were also satisfactory (.66 for interpretation, .47 for integration, and .34 for codification) and significant (p < .001). Taken together, these results lend support to our proposed multilevel, emergent structure of team learning as per Hypothesis 1a.

sec.p: To further examine the appropriateness of our hypothesized structure of team learning emergence (i.e., a second-order construct composed of different factors at different levels), we tested an alternative MSEM model. This model imposed a direct-competing form of emergence by specifying the same factor structure at both levels (i.e., all learning processes were modeled as latent factors at both the individual and team levels of analysis). This alternative model showed poor fit to the data, Bentler-Liang likelihood ratio statistic (165) = 465.7, CFI = .87, RMSEA = .10.

Furthermore, to demonstrate the superiority of using referent-shift measures for interpretation, integration, and codification, we tested two additional multilevel models including self (“I”) referents for these three learning processes (one model had only “I” referents for all learning processes, while the other incorporated both “I” and “we” referents for all learning processes).4 Both models showed significantly worse fit than our proposed multilevel model; very low (and in some cases nonsignificant) team-level factor loadings for the self-referenced items of integration and codification (as compared to their “we” counterparts) and a problematic (first- and second-order) factor structure at the team level of analysis (i.e., in both models, a team-level factor structure for self-, or “I,” referents was identified only for interpretation). These results provided strong evidence in support of our proposed compositional approach (i.e., referent-shift) toward operationalizing integration and codification. Conversely, findings were rather unclear regarding the process of interpretation. In particular, the results of the second model (i.e., including self and team referents for all processes) indicated that our “I”- and “we”-referenced versions of interpretation had similar measurement qualities (i.e., magnitude and significance of factor loadings) at both levels, while they also demonstrated large intercorrelations (above .65). Furthermore, self- and team-referenced interpretation items presented similar levels of within- and between-groups variance (ICC) as well as similar within-group agreement (interrater agreement index). Following van Mierlo, Vermunt, and Rutte (2009), these results could suggest that “I”- and “we”-referenced interpretation items essentially measure the same thing, and thus it would make little difference, statistically, which composition model is used concerning interpretation.

To further investigate this, we specified another direct alternative model, which was the same as our proposed model, except for interpretation, which this time was measured only with self-referenced items (recall that in our original model interpretation was measured with referent-shift items). This model showed satisfactory fit to the data, Bentler-Liang likelihood ratio statistic (123) = 235.6, p < .001, CFI = .95, RMSEA = .06, and the first- and second-order factor loadings for interpretation were high (first-order loadings ranged from .63 to .82; second-order factor loading was .52) and significant (p < .001) at both the within (individual) and between (team) levels. Although these results were clearly inferior to those of our original multilevel model (see Table 3), they may still imply that interpretation can be measured with either self or referent-shift items. However, given the aforementioned theoretical focus of interpretation on the team level of analysis, we recommend that it should be better operationalized with referent-shift items (e.g., “we” or “in our team”; see also Klein et al., 2001; Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999), as operationalized in our original model. To summarize, our proposed multilevel model performed better than all alternative models.

sec.title: Discriminant validity
sec.p: Although the results of the exploratory and the multilevel analyses supported the dimensionality of the a priori (first- and second-order) factor structure of team learning, a thorough assessment of discriminant validity requires comparison with related—but theoretically distinct—constructs. Hypothesis 1a predicted that team learning would be related to, but distinct from, team coordination and communication. To test this, we performed another multilevel analysis including team learning (as a second-order latent factor as per Figure 1) and two additional constructs at the team level: a three-item measure of team coordination (α = .92) and a five-item measure of team communication (α = .91), adopted from Hoegl, Weinkauf, and Gemuenden (2004).

The multilevel model fitted the data well, Bentler-Liang likelihood ratio statistic (133) = 289.7, p < .001, CFI = .97, RMSEA = .04, while all items loaded as expected on their corresponding factors, with high (range .36 to .96) and significant (p < .001) values. Moreover, constraining the correlation between team learning and each of the two additional constructs (i.e., coordination and communication) at the value of 1 resulted in statistically inferior models (i.e., the chi-square difference tests between the unconstrained and the constrained models were significant at p < .01). Overall, the results of the multilevel analysis and additional tests provided strong evidence for the discriminant validity of our team learning measure (Anderson & Gerbing, 1988), as per Hypothesis 1b.

sec.title: Criterion-related and incremental validity
sec.p: Hypothesis 2a predicted that team learning will be positively related to team performance. The results in Table 3 show that team learning (as a second-order factor) has a positive and significant effect on performance at the team level of analysis (β = .34, p < .01), thus providing evidence of criterion-related validity. This lends strong support to Hypothesis 2a.

Hypothesis 2b stated that our second-order factor structure will exhibit incremental validity against existing measures and alternative operationalizations of team learning. For this purpose, we performed a multilevel analysis including Edmondson’s (1999) seven-item measure of team learning (α = .87) and a more traditional operationalization (i.e., average scores) of our team learning items. Results indicated that our second-order latent factor of team learning added significant explanatory value in the prediction of team performance over and above alternative measures (standardized paths were .29 for the latent factor, .06 for Edmondson’s scale, and .20 for the averaged measure), hence demonstrating the incremental validity of our modeling approach (Hammer, Kossek, Yragui, Bodner, & Hanson, 2009; Li & Cropanzano, 2009). This provides support to Hypothesis 2b.

sec.title: Study 3: Confirmation of the Multilevel Factor Structure
Sample and procedures
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to confirm and further examine the generalizability of the multilevel factor structure and construct validity of the team learning scale in a different empirical context. To this end, we used data collected as part of a large research project, which sought to identify factors affecting the performance of collaborative research and development (R & D) projects that were financed under the EU 5th and 6th Framework Programmes (FP5 and FP6). A representative random sample of 54,492 project participants was drawn from a population of 121,661. Information on these participants (i.e., titles and abstracts of the projects in which they had been involved, postal addresses, and e-mails) was retrieved from the CORDIS (Community Research & Development Information Service) database, which is the official information service that provides up-to-date information related to EU activities and initiatives in the fields of R & D and innovation. Questionnaires in English measuring team learning processes and team performance, among many other variables pertaining to project management and performance, were administered electronically after an invitation letter was sent by surface mail, explaining the purpose of the survey and assuring anonymity. Due to space limitations and to lower each respondent’s load (since we utilized the same informants for all variables), team performance in this study was measured with three Likert-type items adopted from Ancona and Caldwell (1992). The scale captured both the efficiency and effectiveness dimensions of team performance.

To enhance the survey response rate, a call center was contracted to call potential respondents for a period of six weeks. The call center was stuffed with 10 calling agents who had full English language skills in addition to mother tongues in French, Italian, German, and Spanish. The agents were extensively trained on the subject matter and the purpose of the exercise. In total, 15,500 calls were registered, and 2,650 follow up e-mails were sent with the details of the survey. Those respondents who had left their respective organizations since project completion, whose address and/or e-mails were unknown, or who expressed no interest in participating in the survey were removed from the database. The entire data collection exercise lasted 10 weeks. Of the 54,492 team members who received the invitation to participate in the survey, 7,098 completed the electronic questionnaire, for an overall response rate of 13.03%. Extensive descriptive analyses established that the data collected were representative of the population from which they were drawn.5

The data used here represent that fraction of the original sample that provided complete information on all the key variables of interest for this study (i.e., learning processes and project performance). Specifically, the sample used in Study 3 contains data on 995 collaborative R & D projects provided by 3,593 team members (on average, 3.6 responses per project) from 258 enterprises and 325 research organizations (i.e., universities and research institutes) from across the European Union’s 27 member states (EU-27). The mean project duration was 36.6 months (SD = 10.6).

Unlike Study 2, in this study the learning process of intuition was measured with referent-shift (“we”) instead of self- (“I”) referents. This is clearly inconsistent with the definition of intuition as an individual-level process, and hence the results pertaining to intuition should be interpreted with caution. We believe, however, that Study 3 is still very useful in that it confirms (as will be shown below) our basic hypothesis of team learning as a second-order, emergent phenomenon, where different learning processes operate at different levels of analysis. An additional problem in Study 3 is that the same informants provided data on both the learning scale and team performance; we had therefore to empirically assess the possibility of common method bias.

First, following the procedures recommended by Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Lee, and Podsakoff (2003), we tested two SEM models: one with all the study’s constructs (i.e., team learning processes and team performance) and another one including also one unmeasured common method variance (CMV) factor, which was linked to the indicators of all constructs. These analyses showed that none of the CMV factor loadings was significant and that the structural path from team learning to team performance remained positive and significant.

Second, we tested another structural model by randomly selecting approximately half of the sampled team members as sources for team learning and the remaining as sources for team performance.6 The results of this model in terms of overall fit were similar to the results of our full-sample model, while the structural path from team learning to team performance did not change much in terms of magnitude and significance (β = .54, p < .001, compared with β = .60, p < .001, in the full model; see below). Taken together, these findings indicated that common method bias did not significantly affect the results of this study (Podsakoff et al., 2003).

sec.title: Multilevel analyses and results
sec.p: Similarly to Study 2, we followed Muthén’s (1994) five-step procedure to assess the multilevel structure of data and examine the emergence of learning at the team level of analysis. Therefore, we first performed a confirmatory factor analysis at the individual level (i.e., N = 3,593) on the four team learning processes and on team performance. We constructed a model with five factors (i.e., intuition, interpretation, integration, codification, and team performance) loading separately, Satorra-Bentler scaled χ2(78) = 511.6, p < .001, CFI = .95, NFI = .94, IFI = .95, RMSEA = .06. All factor loadings were satisfactory (ranging from .50 to .88) and significant (p < .001). Further, the proposed five-factor model performed better than plausible alternative models (e.g., a four-factor model combining interpretation and integration or a three-factor model combining interpretation, integration, and codification), thus providing evidence of convergent and discriminant validity for the constructs studied (Bagozzi et al., 1991).

Next, we computed the ICC(1) for each factor indicator in order to determine the level of between-group variance. The ICC(1) values for all the items ranged from .10 to .22, demonstrating sufficient between-group variation to statistically warrant the use of multilevel analysis (Dyer et al., 2005; James, 1982). We then conducted the MSEM analysis on the sample pooled within-group and between-group covariance matrices (Table 4). As in Figure 1, MSEM modeled our individual- and team-level constructs simultaneously at both levels (i.e., team learning was modeled as a second-order latent factor at the team level composed of first-order latent factors represented at both levels, influencing team performance).
