sec.title: Discriminant validity
sec.p: Similar to Study 2, we empirically assessed the distinctiveness of our measure of team learning by performing another multilevel analysis including two additional group processes: a three-item measure of team coordination (α = .87) and a five-item measure of team communication (α = .83), adopted from Hoegl et al. (2004). The three-factor multilevel model (i.e., team learning, team coordination, and team communication) fitted the data sufficiently well, Bentler-Liang likelihood ratio statistic (109) = 537.6, p < .001, CFI = .96, NFI = .95, IFI = .96, RMSEA = .05, with all item loadings being high (range .58 to .96) and significant (p < .001). Additional evidence for discriminant validity was provided by the fact that in each pairwise test the chi-square difference between the unconstrained and the constrained model (fixing the correlation between any two factors at the value of 1) was significant (p < .01; Anderson & Gerbing, 1988). These results lend support for Hypothesis 1b.

sec.title: Criterion-related and incremental validity
sec.p: Consistent with Study 2, team learning (as a second-order factor) was found to relate positively and significantly with performance at the team level of analysis (β = .60, p < .001; Table 5), thus providing evidence of criterion-related validity. This lends support to Hypothesis 2a.

In addition, to assess the incremental validity of our scale we performed a multilevel analysis including a more traditional operationalization (i.e., average scores) of our team learning items. Results showed that our second-order latent factor of team learning added significant explanatory value in the prediction of team performance over and above the averaged measure (standardized paths were .51 for the latent factor and .42 for the averaged measure), hence demonstrating the incremental validity of our modeling approach, as per Hypothesis 2b.

sec.title: Measurement equivalence
sec.p: Because we collected data from different countries (EU-27 member states), we further tested the assumption that our scales measured equivalent constructs across settings (i.e., measurement equivalence; Mullen, 1995). Given the very large number of countries in the sample (i.e., from all 27 member states) and the highly unbalanced number of observations from each country, it would be impractical to conduct tests of measurement equivalence across all possible country pairs. We therefore first classified countries into four groups (i.e., leaders, followers, moderate innovators, and catching-up)7 based on their innovation performance (European Commission, 2010; recall that the data set for Study 3 was part of a wider research project examining the performance of R & D and innovation projects across the European Union).

ANOVA F statistics on our learning and team performance measures showed no statistical differences (p values ranged from .42 to .94) between the four groups of countries, hence providing evidence of metric equivalence. In addition, we performed simple confirmatory factor analyses across all possible pairs of the four groups of countries, using a five-factor measurement model (i.e., intuition, interpretation, integration, codification, and team performance), to determine whether the assumption of metric equivalence was justified. In these analyses, we constrained the factor loadings to be equal across each pair of country groups and left error variances free to be estimated (Vandenberg & Lance, 2000). In all cases, the five-factor model showed good fit to the data (CFI ranged from .94 to .97; RMSEA ranged from .04 to .07), and factor loadings were similar across each pair of country groups (ranging from .49 to .91; p < .01). Further, a nonsignificant change in chi-square between the constrained and unconstrained models in all confirmatory factor analyses (Δχ2 ranged from 28.27 to 41.48; p values ranged from .27 to .49) provided additional evidence of metric equivalence for our measures.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions
sec.p: The field of team learning has over the years accumulated important scholarly work, which, however, has paid only limited attention to some key conceptual and methodological issues that pertain to its character as a collective phenomenon. In this study, we attempted to portray learning in teams in all its subtlety and complexity as a phenomenon that transcends individual contributions to materialize at the team level. To this end, we integrated learning theory with multilevel thinking to better explain the structure and function of the team learning construct. Specifically, building on the works of Crossan et al. (1999) and Morgeson and Hofmann (1999), we examined (1) how learning occurs and emerges from individual members to become an enduring team property and (2) how team learning functions to produce specific performance outcomes. In so doing, we empirically examined a set of untested propositions regarding learning in teams and validated the measurement of team learning using advanced multilevel methods. Such an approach addresses several recent calls for building ties between individual and team levels of analysis in learning and teamwork research (e.g., Humphrey, Morgeson, & Mannor, 2009; Kozlowski & Ilgen, 2006) and makes an important contribution by clarifying the definition and demonstrating what is important to conceptualize and examine (i.e., structure and function) when studying a significant collective phenomenon such as team learning (Corley & Gioia, 2011).

In keeping with the basic principles of multilevel theory (Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999), our first goal was to clarify and measure the processes through which learning unfolds as a group-level construct, that is, the structure of its emergence. Unlike much of the existing conceptualizations (and measurements) of team learning, we drew from the well-known model of Crossan et al. (1999) to argue that learning originates from individual members and takes shape at the team level through the four sociocognitive processes of intuition, interpretation, integration, and codification. We found strong empirical evidence indicating that these four processes should be modeled at the individual and group levels of analysis, as respectively theorized, and jointly defined learning as an emergent property of the team. To our knowledge, the results reported here provide the first empirical test of propositions derived from Crossan et al.’s framework as they pertain to team learning. Specifically, we demonstrated that individual members’ intuitive cognitions and dialectical interactions through the processes of interpretation and integration, together with knowledge codification, determine the structure of team learning emergence at the team level of analysis. As explained above, intuition is a distinctively individual phenomenon and interpretation “carries” individual contributions onto the team level, thus bridging the gap between the two, whereas integration and codification are manifested at the collective level. It is precisely in these terms that learning in teams is a second-order, emergent collective property and not just the simple aggregation of individual experiences.

As noted above, to our knowledge, these cross-level relationships have never been empirically modeled and verified. Our results are therefore important for a number of reasons. First, and foremost, they portray team learning as what it really is: an emergent, collective property that builds on, but cannot be reduced to, individual contributions. In so doing, we clarify the internal dynamics by which learning unfolds. Specifically, our results point to individual cognition and action as the elemental content of team learning, thereby verifying one of the fundamental premises of organizational learning theory (Fiol & Lyles, 1985). Next, they corroborate the hitherto untested notion that team learning unfolds hierarchically (i.e., from the individual to the team level), thus suggesting that team learning should be conceptualized and measured as a two-level, rather than a single-level, phenomenon. To date, research has failed to recognize explicitly the inherently multilevel nature of team learning, offering incomplete explanations of how learning—a distinctively individual capacity—transforms into a collective property (Kozlowski & Ilgen, 2006; Wilson et al., 2007). Further, in adopting such a multilevel perspective, our analysis delineates the basic cognitive processes through which learning is realized. In this way, we are able to offer a fairly complete account of the activities that team members individually and the group as a whole engage in to process knowledge so as to adapt and improve, consistent with the key propositions of organizational learning theory (Argyris & Schön, 1978; Edmondson, 2002). Finally, our study elucidates the structure of team learning emergence in a way that attempts to align the level of theory with the level of measurement and the level of statistical analysis of the team learning construct. A failure to do so can generate imprecision and lead to controversial or erroneous conclusions, often described as “fallacies of the wrong level” (Rousseau, 1985).

In addition to explicating issues of structure, that is, issues connected to how team learning emerges as a collective phenomenon, our findings shed light on the performance outcomes that team learning generates. This relates to the question of function of an emerging (collective) structure. According to multilevel theorists (e.g., Li & Cropanzano, 2009; Ployhart et al., 2006), the combined investigation of structure and function is essential for developing concrete and meaningful multilevel constructs, such as team learning. As Morgeson and Hofmann note, “A functional analysis provides the scholar with a language and useful heuristic for theory development” (1999: 259).

Seen in this light, a functional analysis of team learning is useful because it reminds us that the processes of team learning and its performance implications are two distinct, albeit closely related, concepts. In some cases, existing research has equated learning occurrence with changes in performance (Wilson et al., 2007). A team, however, may carry out certain learning activities without realizing any concrete performance benefit (Wilson et al., 2007) or even experiencing unproductive results (Bunderson & Sutcliffe, 2003). In this study, we explicitly distinguish learning as an outcome, seen here as the process of codification, from the performance impact of that learning. Our findings, similar to those of other scholars (e.g., Choo et al., 2007; Edmondson, 1999), indicate a positive functional relationship between team learning and team performance.

From a methodological standpoint, the present work offers a fresh empirical contribution by utilizing multilevel construct validation procedures for team learning. Although an increasing body of research employs multilevel analytic techniques in the context of teams (e.g., hierarchical linear modeling; Chen et al., 2007; Humphrey et al., 2009), there has been no attempt to verify the factor structure of team learning simultaneously at the individual and team levels of analysis. To this end, we used MSEM to provide a more robust test of the construct validity of team learning, accounting for the inherent dependence of individual members nested within teams. MSEM adds methodological rigor by testing a complex theoretical construct that transcends multiple levels of analysis (Bliese, Chan, & Ployhart, 2007; Croon & van Veldhoven, 2007).

The pool of items we have developed and the dimensionality of the construct were validated in the first study. Studies 2 and 3 served to establish and further enhance the generalizability of the multilevel factor structure and provided evidence of convergent, discriminant, criterion-related, and incremental validity in two additional, independent samples. In all studies, we obtained very satisfactory factor loadings and fit indices. Taken together, the validated scales of the four constructs offer, we hope, a theoretically rich and methodologically sound basis for further research on team learning as an emergent phenomenon with related antecedents and outcomes that span levels of analysis.

Our findings may also have implications for practice. The fundamental processes of intuition, interpretation, integration, and codification, as conceptualized in this work, along with their corresponding measures, could serve as validated diagnostic tools for improving team design and adaptability. Following such diagnostics, teams could be designed and structured in such ways as to enhance intermember communication and collective action in accordance with the basic dimensions of learning processes outlined here. The scales developed here offer firms an easily administered and valid instrument for assessing team learning. Practitioners, therefore, may now have at their disposal an instrument, specifically developed and validated at the group level of analysis, to use during team-building and development activities, learning orientation surveys, and selection of new team members.

sec.title: Limitations and Future Research Directions
sec.p: As with all empirical work, ours is not without limitations that future research could seek to address. First, interested scholars could validate the scales developed here and replicate our findings in different empirical contexts. In all three studies, we investigated innovative project teams operating in technology- and knowledge-intensive environments. Such teams perform highly complex tasks that demand finely tuned learning activities, aiming to produce new knowledge that is critical to their success. Although our data sets consisted of teams from different national and industrial contexts, there is considerable merit in research confirming the present findings in teams that perform tasks of routine nature or that operate within less knowledge-intensive environments; this will undoubtedly add to the generalizability of our scales.

Future research could also provide a thorough examination of the nomological network surrounding team learning across the individual and team levels of analysis. Previous work has shown that factors such as individual experience (Reagans, Argote, & Brooks, 2005), team psychological safety (Edmondson, 1999), and group cohesion (Wong, 2004) are significantly related to a team’s learning behavior. Those factors can affect the system of interactions among group members, which, in turn, may have an important role in determining the emergence of learning as a collective phenomenon. Our work clearly falls short of examining these effects. Additional analyses in this direction will be particularly useful for the validation of our findings.

Another limitation pertains to the nature of our data, which were cross-sectional and did not cover the longitudinal pattern of team learning emergence. Our cross-sectional multilevel models examined how learning emerges hierarchically, from the level of the individual to that of the team. Clearly, our treatment of learning emergence is static: It involves the simultaneous examination of different sociocognitive processes at different levels of analysis. Although this hierarchical approach has evolved as the primary means of explicating multilevel phenomena (Mathieu & Chen, 2011), it clearly fails to provide an account of how learning unfolds over time. A longitudinal design would thus be a very promising line of research; it could offer important explanations on how, for instance, different learning processes develop at different rates and influence each other over time (i.e., what Crossan and her colleagues call “feed-forward” and “feedback” learning flows). To illustrate, intuition as a lower (individual-) level process may develop more quickly and affect interpretation when a team is at the forming stage (Kozlowski & Klein, 2000), whereas codification may feed back and affect individual intuitions when the team task is near completion. A longitudinal design would therefore allow us to better articulate the dynamic nature of learning in teams, emerging episodically within different stages of a team’s life cycle in response to shifting task conditions (Marks et al., 2001). Future research utilizing new methodologies such as latent growth modeling can thus integrate hierarchical and longitudinal multilevel approaches to extend our pattern of results and further advance the learning literature.

Furthermore, like much of the existing work in this area (e.g., Gibson & Vermeulen, 2003; Van der Vegt & Bunderson, 2005), most of our data were self-reported measures. Although there is evidence that people generally perceive their social environments accurately and provide correct performance evaluations (Alper, Tjosvold, & Law, 2000), utilizing “objective” indexes could offer a more robust test of the functional relationship between team learning and team performance. Further, in Study 3 the learning process of intuition was measured with referent-shift items, which contradicts its individual-level definition. Although these concerns are somewhat mitigated by the fact that intuition was included in the empirical models only at the individual level (as in Study 2), its measurement properties should be interpreted with caution. Our preferred measurement of intuition is that of Study 2 (see Table 3).

In addition, in Study 3 the team learning and team performance measures were collected from the same respondents (i.e., team members) and, thus, may have been affected by common source bias. Even though the results of various additional analyses and tests provided evidence against the presence of common source bias, we cannot rule out its potential effect. Nonetheless, we note that all our data were collected from multiple respondents for each team studied, while in Study 2 different sources were employed for measuring team learning processes (i.e., team members) and team performance (i.e., team supervisors); these increase our confidence in the validity of our results.

Finally, we consider it important to emphasize that even though we utilize key aspects of Crossan et al.’s (1999) learning framework, our focus in this study is learning in teams, not organizations. Our focus on team learning extends the theoretical argumentation of Crossan and her colleagues by introducing an intermediary step to their model. Recall that Crossan et al. proceed from integration at the team level to organization-wide institutionalization of what has been learned. Our model suggests an intervening step in the transition from the team to the organization, that of knowledge codification occurring at the team level of analysis.

Crossan et al. note that “Institutionalized [i.e., organizational] learning cannot capture all the ongoing learning at the individual and group levels” (1999: 530). Our model and findings imply that institutionalized learning will likely capture only learning that teams are able to codify. If this conjecture is valid, it opens up promising possibilities for future research on why organizational learning and renewal are so difficult to achieve. Teams do not always codify what they have learned; even if they do so, there always remains some important tacit element in the knowledge gained that is not amenable to codification. What underlies a team’s propensity to codify (parts of) the knowledge gained from its operations? Under what conditions can the team do so effectively? These and similar questions can perhaps provide significant insights on the question of organizational renewal along the path Crossan et al. developed in their seminal article.

In conclusion, the work at hand demonstrates the value of multilevel theory and related analytic methods for understanding the emergence of learning in teams. We have put forth considerable effort not to commit fallacies of the wrong level through aligning the level of theory with the level of statistical analysis and the level of measurement. Understanding how learning emerges through intuition, interpretation, integration, and codification is likely to be an important means of improving not only team but also organizational performance.

fn.p: Crossan, Lane, and White’s (1999) ultimate goal is to examine how organizations (not teams) learn. They therefore conceptualize institutionalization at the organizational level, referring to it as a process “of embedding learning that has occurred by individuals and groups into the organization” (Crossan et al., 1999: 525). However, the key idea in the conceptualization of this process can be transferred and applied to the study of learning at the team level in that it represents the direct, codified outcomes of learning that have resulted in the course of interactions among members within the team; it is in this way that team learning persists over time, independent of individual contributions (Gibson & Vermeulen, 2003; Wilson, Goodman, & Cronin, 2007).

The learning process of interpretation has a primarily social (collective) character. It initiates at the conscious elements of individual members, but it is constructed and fully realized as a shared, team-level property via a series of cross-member interactions. As Crossan et al. argue, “Interpreting is a social activity that creates and refines common language, clarifies images, and creates shared meaning and understanding. Equivocality [i.e., diversity of individual understandings] is reduced through interpreting. . . . Groups will have an interpretive capacity related to the makeup of the group and to the group dynamics. As the interpretive process moves beyond the individual and becomes embedded within the workgroup, it becomes integrative. Individual interpretive processes come together around a shared understanding of what is possible, and individuals interact and attempt to enact that possibility” (1999: 528). This means that interpretation is shaped as a group process reflecting a socially constructed reality and thus should be better measured with referent-shift (e.g., “we” or “in our team”) items (Klein, Conn, Smith, & Sorra, 2001; Morgeson & Hofmann, 1999).

The results of Steps 3 and 4 of Muthén’s (1994) procedure are not reported here because they were (and typically are) very similar in value to the estimates of the final multilevel model. In addition, our multilevel structural equation modeling model converged to a solution without problems, which could potentially necessitate starting values (e.g., for factor loadings) provided by Steps 3 and 4 (for similar approaches see Dyer, Hanges, & Hall, 2005, and Hirst, Van Knippenberg, & Zhou, 2009).
We are grateful to an anonymous reviewer for suggesting these analyses.

For example, the distribution of the received questionnaires is 70.2% for EU 5th Framework Programmes (FP5) and 29.8% for EU 6th Framework Programmes (FP6) projects, which is almost identical to the distribution in the original sample. Similarly, a detailed breakdown of survey responses per program (FP5 and FP6) for the different thematic areas, funding “instruments,” and types of participating organizations showed that the data are representative of the aggregate numbers in the sample. Additional details are available from the authors upon request.
